body:
@DonalEvans @agingade @jhuynh1 @nabarunnag 
This is ready for review now, cheers.

In case anyone keeps working on this, I did a bit more work to allow launching locators and servers and running embedded webapps: https://github.com/jdeppe-pivotal/geode/commit/e56aa2c2aeaeda4bbe1e78d69004fb549590020e
@dschneider-pivotal  Can you take another look at this pull request?
@Bill Should I merge this?
@jhuynh1 @upthewaterspout Can you review this and merge it?
@bschuchardt @pivotal-jbarrett  Are there still concerns with this PR?
@dschneider-pivotal @pivotal-jbarrett  Are you satisfied with the changes? the failure is a known one. It has been fixed, @mivanac  just needs to rebase and push or we rebase and merge. Thoughts?
Failure in DistributedTestOpenJDK11 is PersistentPartitionedRegionWithRedundancyDUnitTest which is unrelated. Looks like that is a recently added flaky test.
@mhansonp I have already approved these changes.

> @mhansonp I have already approved these changes.

Thanks.
@davebarnes97 Are you finally including the function in bookbindery? I have seen you reverted the change.

Thanks for adding this test! I think it exposes a deficiency in the `FunctionAccessController` for which I have opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7290. In this particular case the function call results in a NPE, but that isn't ever visible to the caller. The failure just ends up being a 500 error.
/gemfire-api context is deprecated, we should use /geode instead.

From my evaluation it appears that the problem is between the time that the `gfsh` process has launched and the test calls `getOutputText()`. At this point the `ProcessLogger` has not had enough time to process all the output from the gfsh process. I'd suggest augmenting `GfshExecution.awaitTermination()` to also wait on `ProcessLogger` to 'complete' - that would imply to wait until its `StreamGobbler` threads have stopped.
@jinmeiliao thanks for the comment, this will simplify the code then
Thanks for investigating this @jdeppe-pivotal!
@jmelchio
Thanks @jdeppe-pivotal! I re-worked this PR per your suggestion. Now `GfshExecution.awaitTermination()` will also wait for `ProcessLogger` to finish collecting output from the process.
Looks like this is breaking some acceptance tests... will fix.
@jmelchio
Since these changes are approved, I will merge this PR.
UT and update inRecovery logic added.

Force pushed due to, not able to normal push
([rejected]              feature/GEODE-6807 -> feature/GEODE-6807 (non-fast-forward))
feel free to include `[skip ci]` in the commit comment for this type of change, as running the full battery of Geode tests has no benefit...
Approval by @jhuynh1 satisfies my concern regarding technical review.

This is first part of work, to update solution and add UT.
I will add also ConcurrentTestRunner based test.

It looks good to me now except for the need for the concurrent test

@jmelchio

Thanks for reviewing this @jhuynh1!. Regarding your comments and questions, please find my answers below.

> I'm kind of curious if there is a way to not cache if we know the result set is size 1 or some small number. Mostly whether we should even explore that in a different ticket. Over optimization at this point probably.

Agreed, we can try to figure this out in another ticket.

> Is it possible for someone to access a cq and grab it's query context and somehow used the cached values in it's query context to execute methods/field it shouldn't have access to?

I don't think it's possible, no... that "someone" would need knowledge about internal Geode classes **plus** permissions/priviledges to connect to the cluster, deploy code and execute queries and/or functions alltogether. Would be happy to double check anyway, but I think it'll require some time (probably a new ticket too?).
I'm working on PR #4104 which includes this change.  If you want to help out on getting that one merged we can combine our efforts :-)
On #4104 I skipped this upgrade because it was causing `RestAPIsWithSSLDUnitTest` to fail with a cert error.  If you can figure that out it would be great!
Unrelated issues cased JDK11 tests to fail. Merging without rerunning those JDK11 tests.

@mkevo I think the SSL failures can be fixed by switching `SSLContectFactory` to `SSLContextFactory.Server` as per these Jetty issues:
https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3464
https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3466
https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3554

> LGTM, but I'd love to see a `Unit` or `Integration` test to verify the changes before merging the PR :-).

Unit test added

> @mkevo I think the SSL failures can be fixed by switching `SSLContectFactory` to `SSLContextFactory.Server` as per these Jetty issues:
> [eclipse/jetty.project#3464](https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3464)
> [eclipse/jetty.project#3466](https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3466)
> [eclipse/jetty.project#3554](https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3554)

Thanks for an advice! I will take a look on it.

> I'm working on PR #4104 which includes this change. If you want to help out on getting that one merged we can combine our efforts :-)

Yes of course :-)
I will close this PR and add related link on the ticket.
@DonalEvans @BenjaminPerryRoss
we decide to move Links back to the public api because extension developers will need a concrete class to create the Links object when they implement AbstractConfiguration.getLinks() call.

@jmelchio

> ~Please don't merge this yet â€” it seems there might be a case where this doesn't record the correct times for function executions without a result.~

I believe this issue is fixed. See [comment](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4135#discussion_r336275403).
@jdeppe-pivotal @kirklund Do you think we can merge this or should we wait on more reviews?

CQ tests were failing because the `getQueryService()` method on client side (invoked when creating the new `ExecutionContext`) causes an implicit `DEFAULT` Pool [initialization](https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/GemFireCacheImpl.java#L4186-L4196), which can not be avoided when using custom pools as the tests do.
The `ExecutionContext` now uses a no-op authorizer when created from a client cache: authorization and authentication logic happens only on server side anyways, and the authorizer will be obtained from the cluster configuration service directly instead of the query service when OQL security is fully implemented ([GEODE-6983](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6983)).
@DonalEvans @BenjaminPerryRoss

Hey @mivanac, jus a friendly reminder: everyone, even committers, should wait for at least one positive review (aka approval) before merging PRs into `develop`, even when those PR are only related to changes in test classes.
And congratulations for becoming for a Geode committer, BTW!.

1. Versions of dependent jars can be different to what is required/used by Geode itself
   I may be wrong, but I thought the gradle version conflict resolution will always resolve to use the same version of jackson libs even if the web component is using a different version than the core.

1. Since we're publishing wars (and they can be referenced and used in Spring apps for example) they should definitely be self contained.
   but the wars are not self-contained even now, they definitely doesn't include the geode-core jars that it needs. Any Spring apps that includes this war will have to pull in geode-core.jar which will pull in jackson libs.
Please review @kirklund @demery-pivotal @mhansonp

1. What I meant was just that the 'web' versions and 'core' versions *could* be different if needed. (Say we wanted the web components to use Spring 5, for example). Also, we should consider situations where components are not started/managed by `gfsh` but rather by something like *Spring Boot* where it's much easier for a user to adjust the versions of dependencies.
2. It is true that the web components do not include *geode*, however I don't think it's ever a good idea to implicitly depend on a transitive dependency of an immediate dependency. (Hopefully that makes sense). As much as possible, we should be isolating and encapsulating the dependencies of the web components.

There is a LOT more work to do to make Geode compile on JDK11.  Last time we tried this, we ended up backing out much of the progress that had been made such as adding jvm args `["--add-opens", "java.xml/jdk.xml.internal=ALL-UNNAMED", "--add-opens", "java.base/jdk.internal.module=ALL-UNNAMED", "--add-opens", "java.base/java.lang.module=ALL-UNNAMED"]` due to the realization that to properly support jigsaw modules is going to require breaking changes so can't be done until Geode 2.0, so rather than have very limit support for compiling on Java 11, it is better that it not be possible at all for the time being.

Please also review geode-web-management/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/management/internal/rest/swagger/SwaggerConfig.java:69

> So we don't need to change the place where gfsh-dependency.jar is created? where do we add the geode-version.jar dependency to gfsh?

gfshDependencies is created from geode-all-bom with a few specific exclusions, so it picks up everything else automatically including geode-serialization.

> I thought we were going to measure these in Get70, to include all of the overhead, and to ensure that we are measuring only gets that originated outside the server. Has this changed?

At first, we noticed that `Get70` calls into `LocalRegion.get()` which is already instrumented with `RegionPerfStats.endGet()`. We (perhaps naively) assumed that we could just use the existing instrumentation instead of adding a new method to `RegionPerfStats`.

When we looked more closely at what's calling `RegionPerfStats.endGet()`, it turns out that java client "get all" operations, GFSH gets, and REST API gets are all recorded if we use this method to instrument. While this may actually be desirable, we aren't sure what else might be recorded if we use this method. We don't want peer-to-peer get operations to be recorded, for example.

> I'm ok with counting gets from REST, GFSH, Functions, etc. Dale has a point about timing the overhead in Get70 but I don't feel strongly about it.

If we do decide to leave the instrumentation as-is, then we should probably add some additional test for "get all", GFSH, REST, etc.

> I thought we were going to measure these in Get70, to include all of the overhead, and to ensure that we are measuring only gets that originated outside the server. Has this changed?

After discussing with @kirklund and @demery-pivotal, I will update this PR to perform measurements in `Get70` and update the timers' descriptions to clarify that they are only recording gets from a java or native client.

Tests use RestoreSystemProperties rule to reset the system properties.

This should not cause side effects if not lock memory using the new system property introduced, compared to the unknown side effect if using the original ALLOW_MEMORY_OVERCOMMIT system property setting.

The current solution breaks the backward compatibility of the API as it can be observed in the CI failing tests (ClientAuthorizationCQDUnitTest).
Either the proposal should be revisited or a new solution must be devised.
@DonalEvans @BenjaminPerryRoss

I know this is still in draft, but do statistics, monitoring, and thread related classes really belong in geode-logging? These classes don't look like they have anything to do with logging. I really want to keep geode-log4j and geode-logging very strictly about "logging".
I accidentally merged this before a test was finished running and it is a problem.

@kirklund I understand your point.  The challenge here is to not "boil the ocean" and my plan was to test out moving this to a non-core module then look at what new module they might reside within.....   thanks for checking out the Draft
Please review @demery-pivotal @kirklund @mhansonp

@DonalEvans: thanks for reviewing.
@jhuynh1: I didn't change the existing tests, just refactored the class to get rid of deprecated code and warnings, and added some new tests with meaningful names to test my changes. I'll dive into these particular tests to figure out what they're doing and change the names as requested, though, thanks.
@DonalEvans

The conflict in `AbstractMeterAssert.java` may be resolved by taking their changes and discarding mine. PR #4203 fixed the same issue in a better way (i.e. handing the case where the meter is null).

When squashing and merging, please use the following commit message:
```
GEODE-7326: Add cache gets timers

- Add timers to record get operations from a Java client
- Tag each timer with region name and result (hit/miss)
- Close existing entries gauge when closing RegionPerfStats
- Improve micrometer assertj assertions
- Make public fields immutable on Get70.Entry

Co-authored-by: Aaron Lindsey <alindsey@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Kirk Lund <klund@apache.org>
Co-authored-by: Dale Emery <demery@pivotal.io>
```

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Equals method does not inspect argument type
Out of curiosity, are we timing out more often now?  Did we add more tests or did something impact our test run speed?

> Do we have a test for testing invalid authorizers and verifying what the cache ends up installing?

The `QueryConfigurationServiceImplTest` covers that case, as it verifies that the authorizer is not updated if an invalid authorizer is specified. An invalid authorizer here is defined as something that either doesn't inherit from `MethodInvocationAuthorizer`, doesn't have a public constructor that takes a `Cache` and `Set<String>` or that fails to be instantiated.
I had to rebase the branch to fix merge conflicts, but not all feedback/requests for changes have yet been applied.

The only purpose of HATEOAS is to make endpoint discovery easier (for a human, generally, although the dream was for automated discovery).  It's been suggested to me that a simpler way to accomplish that might just be to redirect `/` to `/docs`.  That should work just as well for humans, but then why are we doing any HATEOAS at all...?

It's also been suggested that `/` may require authentication -- only `/docs` and a few select paths are explicitly configured as public.  Before accepting this PR, it would likely be a good idea to make `/` public...
Is this solution with impacts moved to AbstractRegionMapPut, OK with you, or something else is needed?
